awd_titl_txt: Thinking Outside the Box: Integrating Dynamic Mathematics to Advance Computational Thinking for Diverse Student Populations
awd_abstract_narration:
The focus of the project is the integration of computer science and mathematics concepts in a middle school course. The project's goal is to explain students' learning of four concepts that are part of both mathematics and computer science: variables, expressions, loops and abstraction.  The project will design a middle school computer science course to incorporate the mathematics concepts. It will explore technology-based dynamic representations that are part of an interactive computer-based system. The research results and product development are potentially transformative to mathematics, science, and computer science teaching and learning in light of the expansion of computer science courses nationwide and current national mathematics and science standards. The project has strong potential for impact because it focuses on signature concepts from mathematics and computational thinking that are both areas of overlap and foundational concepts across a range of grade levels and courses. The STEM+Computing Partnership (STEM+C) program seeks to advance multidisciplinary integration of computing in STEM teaching and learning through applied research and development across one or more domains; integration of STEM in computer science; and broadening participation in computer science. Investments are made in critical areas of pedagogy, pre-service and in-service teacher professional development. The ECR program contribution to the funding of this project, emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that generates foundational knowledge in the field.  Investments in ECR are made in critical areas that are essential, broad and enduring:  STEM learning and STEM learning environments, broadening participation in STEM, and STEM workforce development.

Considering the concepts dynamically is a significant and potentially transformative departure from current practice in mathematics and computer science. The research questions examine learning outcomes for students and a theory of action for engaging computational thinking in diverse classrooms. The project will begin by creating assessments of students' conceptual understanding. Then, it will employ a design-based research study for creating technology platforms and activities for students. Finally, it will refine the theory of action for implementing the course. The data collection and analysis includes case studies of students' learning to support the research results and to refine the curriculum materials. Teachers and school district leaders are involved with the design and implementation of the materials. Teachers will be interviewed about their implementation of the course and about students that have been identified for deeper case study analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Programming is considered a key skill that all K-12 students must learn today as part of their school education. Programming is a key ingredient not only in computer science (CS) learning but also in the context of STEM and Computing (STEM+C) integration. Certain programming concepts such as variables, expressions, loops, and abstraction ('VELA') are foundational to programming as well as mathematical and scientific modeling. However, these concepts are hard to grasp by novice learners of programming as students harbour several misconceptions related to how these foundational concepts work. Typical approaches to teaching programming to date have not succeeded in helping learners engage with these concepts in ways that are approachable and friendly, and yet meaningful from a deeper learning perspective. 'Thinking Outside the Box: Integrating Dynamic Mathematics to Advance Computational Thinking for Diverse Student Populations' was an exploratory project that examined innovative ways to help middle school students engage with the VELA concepts of introductory programming through designed interactive activities?both digital and unplugged?before they encountered and used these concepts in programming.


For our innovations in this project, we drew inspiration from the recognized potential and impact of dynamic representational technologies in primary and secondary mathematics education over the past twenty years, particularly Dynamic Geometry software such as The Geometer's Sketchpad. By focusing on technological representations of computing content that are directly and interactively manipulatable, and that preserve global correctness, we sought to investigate whether similar pedagogic impacts are possible in learning of programming. The approach was founded on the belief that exploiting the synergies of mathematical and computational thinking to help learners build robust mental models of VELA concepts in both disciplines has the potential to help learners who struggle with poor preparation in mathematics. 


Four digital game-like activities and microworlds and two unplugged activities that targeted the VELA concepts were designed? Graphical Looping, Story Variables, Cats & Ladders, Dice Game, Three Switches, and Alarm Clock (see Table 1). These activities, along with lesson plans and worksheets for teachers and students (respectively), are openly available at http://csforall.sri.com, and can be plugged into any introductory programming curriculum in middle or high school regardless of programming language being taught or the context of learning coding.


Table 1. Suite of VELA Activities

 

The project also developed a summative assessment for middle school introductory programming (focusing on foundational concepts) using Evidence-Centered Design, a principled methodology for assessment design. The VELA assessment is pencil-paper based to be administered in a class period, but is now also deployed online on an NSF-funded assessment platform http://edfinity.com. Like the VELA activities, the assessment has broad usability for any introductory programming curriculum.

 

Empirical studies were conducted in middle school classrooms that reflected the diversity of the large urban school district in California that they were a part of. CS teachers from these classrooms received professional development on the VELA activities and curriculum (that also involved learning programming in Scratch). Classroom data on assessment performance revealed that all three classrooms showed significant gains from pre-to-post intervention.

 

Also, learning gains were not significantly correlated to grade, gender, or prior academic preparation (as captured by scores on standardized State mathematics and English tests), suggesting that, in aggregate, all students learned from the VELA curriculum regardless of student characteristics and prior academic preparation. In addition, students who learned from the VELA intervention created free-choice open-ended final programming projects that were significantly more sophisticated in their use of VELA constructs and scores significantly higher than a comparative dataset of similar final projects from other non-VELA classrooms in the same school district. 

 

Qualitative case studies with three classroom teachers and twelve students revealed that at an individual level, there is room for improvement. Classroom factors that impacted VELA enactment for some individual teachers and students included (lack of) time for conceptual exploration with the activities, the (fast) pacing of the intervention, the (lack of) differentiation for differently abled students, the physical arrangement of some classrooms and (variability in) teachers' own conceptual grasp of VELA concepts. 

 

In addition to the open-access VELA activities and assessment, project findings were actively disseminated to research communities through 10 conference presentations and webinars at AERA, SIGCSE, NCME, ICLS, and STEM+C PI meetings, in addition to journal articles on the concepts before coding approach to teaching programming, the design of the VELA activities through translating design principles from dynamic representations in mathematics, and the case study research into classroom factors impacting learning of programming.


In the spirit of epistemological pluralism and the mantra of Computer Science for All, this exploratory project investigated innovative pedagogical approaches to teaching foundational computing concepts so as to provide varied pathways to further student success in deeper learning of programming. The VELA activities and assessment have been shown to be impactful and are accessible for broad use by the K-12 CS and STEM teaching communities.
